Basic Sentences - Subjunctives The mood is used to express notions that are supposed, doubted, feared or desired. They are not currently reality. Subjunctives are not used very much in English and the examples look something like conditionals but in first person, such as:
If I were in charge, I would fix the problem. If I were a man, I would be a soccer player.
In the examples above, the subjuctive verb is were and it follows the conditional word if. The consequence is normally in the future form. The consequence can also be presented before the subjunctive condition, as shown in:
I would fix the problem if I were in charge. I would like to be a soccer player if I were a man.
Subjunctives are most commonly used in embedded clauses in many languages, following main verbs such as demand, doubt, wish, fear and hope plus the complementizer that. (The embedded clause examples will be discussed further in
Complement Clauses.) English examples include:
I hope that Benjamin will improve quickly. I demand that he study.
